commentBody: Managed a personal best time on this quite easy-for-a-Thursday puzzle. I enjoyed it well enough, but was hoping for a *bit* more struggle than I got.

It‚Äôs unfortunate how easy that puzzle was. Now my personal best Thursday will never be beaten until another unnecessarily easy puzzle comes along on a Thursday. 

Reasonably fun, but the slavish adherence to the pi day theme put an otherwise easy puzzle on what should‚Äôve been a much harder day.
Was hanging out with my friend who took me to the US Open. He doesn't do crosswords, but he got a kick out of the 1968 tennis clue

As Europeans, PI DAY would be July 22 (i.e. 22/7) for STEPHEN HAWKING and ALBERT EINSTEIN.  (Einstein did become an American citizen in his later years.)

If this puzzle had been held until July 22, it would have run on a Monday.  Would that have been a better placement?
Very easy for a Thursday but still fun.
I really enjoyed Deb's story about the Indiana Pi Bill. Legislative humor, indeed.

14A missed a chance to tie in with the theme:

‚ÄúInvitation suitable for today‚Äôs date‚Äù: 

EAT UP!

I think I may do a raspberry cranberry combo. Each serving approximately œÄ/3 radians. I‚Äôd ask you all over, but that would be a bit irrational.
I agree that the theme was a bit loose, but I enjoyed the theme answers as well as the other fill. I finished the puzzle in 2.2œÄ minutes.

One of my daughters, born on 27 August, worked for several years as the regulator of taxicabs at San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency. She seems to have been predestined mathematically for this job, since her birthdate, 8/27, is a combination of two cubes. A mathematical taxicab number is the smallest number expressing the sum of two cubes n different ways, e.g. 1729 a.k.a. Ta(2), the sum of the cubes of 1 and 12 and the cubes of 9 and 10. She started work at SFMTA in 2008, the year in which the largest known taxicab number, Ta(6), was discovered.

I'll echo what others have almost uniformly said so far: that was quite the breezy Thursday puzzle! 

I enjoyed it for the short time I solved it . . . well, that is except for 56 Down. (The last thing I want or need to think about before going to bed is the f@%#ing NRA . . . ugh.)

No love for the big pi grid art in middle of the 14x16 grid? Or a comment about lateral symmetry instead of rotational? I thought the grid was apt and cool. I'm also in the "really easy for a Thursday" camp, but that's OK. 

On Pi Day, my wife & and are leaving for a journey down under; when we get to New Zealand it will already be the 16th. (Is 3:16 "John Day"...?) So no Ides of March for us this year, and I'm worried about my streak, which is closing in on 1500.

That was easy as pi, but lots of fun.  

Today i learned that Albert Einstein was born on March 14th and that Stephen Hawking died on that date.  

Nicely done, Jeffrey.

Has geocaching always required a GPS?

Lovely puzzle and great column - I did not realize that about those two famous scientists!

This was so much fun. And like others, I didn't know about the Pi connection with these two.

üçûüçüüç†

So was this a squared circle?





cc: emu handler
Not my best (Thursday) time, but I did complete it in 13:42, which is kind of an anagram of 3.142, I guess ¬Ø\_(„ÉÑ)_/¬Ø

Curses!


My MPG* let me down. The last in a series ended ny series of gold estrellas. Oh well, sometimes repetition, as in clues echoed through the week, just dont stick to the dimmed gray areas covered by my dense pia mater.

Et tu,  et al! And thus, the stars fall.

*memory per grid
Yes, it was easy, and yes, I smashed my Thursday record, but it was still a lot of fun. I appreciated the grid art, the placement of PIDAY, the inclusion of Euler, IPAS and ALES both, etc.

I didn't notice the œÄ in the grid and I didn't know that it was also Einstein's birthday.  Euler's identity is just beautiful.  Bringing together the irrational constants œÄ and e as well as the imaginary number i in one equation is breathtaking.
I think that was the easiest Thursday ever for me. It helped that I got STEPHEN HAWKING, PI DAY, and ALBERT EINSTEIN on my first pass.

Yes, the puzzle was 
easy-breezy for a Thursday, but I was engaged all the way through, enjoying every bit of it. 
Many thanks to Mr. Martinovic for a very clever Pi Day tribute, and to the editing team for choosing to run it on the appropriate date despite the lack of trickiness. 

Further, I loved learning the interesting fact about Einstein and Hawkins, and it wowed me that such great minds were connected to 3.14 as a date of the birth of one and passing of the other. 
Cue the Twilight Zone music.

I don't celebrate Pi Day, but it always puts a smile on my face. 
Maybe it's because I love numbers and math, and Pi has astounded me since the first encounter. 
Or maybe it's because every 3/14, I call my dad and wish him a Happy Pi Day since "father" in Portuguese is "pai," and pronounced exactly the same, he he.

Last but not least, thank you to Joel Fagliano -- we couldn't have asked for a better sub while Will Shortz heals. 
But to Will Shortz I say: please know that with every puzzle, every day, best thoughts and wishes are being sent your way. That's every. single. day.

The puzzle held my attention but did not strain my brain.  More like a Wednesday than a Thursday (kept thinking, uh, where's the catch?), but scientifically correct for bowing to the magical pi. Filled with some heavy hitters mathematically speaking, names we knew, but with a bit of a twist in the identities, sometimes suggesting that the clue was harder to come up with than the fill.

Where was Waldo in 1899? Saving Indiana from the nonsense coming out of Dr. Goodwin's pi hole. 

Good job, Jeffrey.  It was a fun solve, and fun to talk about as well.
Just came here to say I finished in less than half my average Thursday time; so I know this is easy for a Thursday puzzle. (but still feeling pretty proud of myself!)
Lovely puzzle, but since we got a Tuesday puzzle for Thursday could we get a Thursday puzzle for Friday?

I finished this puzzle in my average Tuesday time. I never thought I would say this, but I would have enjoyed a more challenging puzzle on a Thursday. I suppose being on the constructor's wavelength played its part, still... This seemed too easy.

Then again, I will always take too easy over too hard ü§£

.

.

.

Shoo, emu.

The editors of the various NYT games should get together on a standardized dictionary.   The word RIATA  has been used many times in crossover puzzles but for some reason it is not acceptable in the Spelling Bee.  I could say the same about Dado and a few other words as well.   it would be nice if you picked one dictionary and stuck with it.

I loved the concept and the irrational (mathematically) but rational (thematically) linking of Hawking and Einstein. The rest was pretty easy for a Thursday but, hey, it's pi day, And thanks to Deb for that hilarious history of the Indiana Pi Bill.
This felt more like a monthly bonus puzzle than a thursday

Faster than Tuesday and Wednesday this week, new Thursday PB (exactly œÄ + 5 minutes)





run at 'em, u flightless bird!

I‚Äôm delighted that Jeffrey‚Äôs Pi-Day offering was edited by the incomparable JOEL FAGLIANO. You may remember that Joel was the constructor of the greatest X-Word puzzle ever to appear in the New York Times: ‚ÄúHeard at the Movies‚Äù on August 31, 2014. Check it out: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/31/2014 If you like Mondegreens, you‚Äôll love what Joel did with these clues: HONDA WATT AFFRONT (On the Waterfront, the best movie Oscar winner)

@Deb mentions that pi is the ‚Äúmathematical constant that is used to help calculate the area of a circle.‚Äù  Well, yes, but it is strictly defined as the ratio of the circle‚Äôs circumference to its diameter.  Pi is necessary to calculate the area enclosed by a circle but its definition is the ratio mentioned above.  üòä

Like others have described here, today‚Äôs time was a PB for me.  I had read earlier today that Einstein was born on this day and Hawking was a good guess.  Music on first attempt and no lookups.  Felt more like Monday to me ‚Ä¶
Like so many others, this was a fun breeze. I‚Äôve long known that ALBERT EINSTEIN was born this day as he shares a birthday with my brother. Happy 60th B (and Pi) Day, Andy!!

My love for numbers like pi and e is irrational, but constant.

(It's even transcendental.)
I wasn't familiar with 24A, but reading up on it it doesn't seem to be the first at all? Project SCORE was built as a communications satellite and launched 17 years before RCA was founded

Conceptually brilliant.  Just everything was so well thought out. 
The grid art. 
The notable scientists that came and went in this day. 
The dimensions of the grid to fit the number. 

My goodness. What planning.  And what execution.  Even OHO which I wasn‚Äôt a fan of, at least had grid symmetry. 

Certainly not the hardest puzzle. But gets my vote for puzzle of the year, thus far. For observation and execution. 

Masterclass Jeffrey.
Thank you for a delightful solve. And Euler too. You made my Pi Day :-)
Dang Emus.
I kept waiting for the tricky part, and then got 33 Down. 3/14 falls on a Thursday, and I‚Äôm happy to see it commemorated so cleverly.

Well, opening the puzzle was a œÄ in the face! No clowning around here, but it was a fun puzzle, with a bit of meat to it, and lots of variety in the clues and answers. Nice to see that the puzzle is in good hands with Joel subbing for Will, who I hope is proceeding quickly on the road to recovery.

Thanks, Jeffrey!

I had not heard the term "purple prose" before today's puzzle, but was able to figure it out.  Upon finishing the puzzle, I decided to do a Monday from the archive and randomly settled on Feb 2, 2004.  Wouldn't you know "purple prose" was almost in the exact same position! Apparently it's a term I'm meant to remember.

Although I‚Äôm usually among the crowd clamoring for a tricky, twisty Thursday puzzle, I‚Äôll add my voice to those who found the cleverness of the well worked out theme and the grid construction in this puzzle to more than compensate for the lack of rebuses or other such gimmickry.  

I got off to a good start by knowing that a schooner has two MASTS, courtesy of having read Patrick O‚ÄôBrian‚Äôs Aubrey - Maturin books, and once the theme became clear the rest was a breeze.

The amazing coincidence of Einstein's birth and Hawking's death both occurring on Pi Day is akin, in long odds but delightful symmetry, with Thomas Jefferson and John Adams, long-time rivals and later pen pals, both dying on the same day, July 4, 1826 -- and, for the perfect icing on that cake, that date being the 50th anniversary of the signing of the document -- the Declaration of Independence -- to which they were both so indelibly attached.  

The universe gives us some fantastical stories.  I wonder, if you gave Einstein, Hawking, and Euler the task of calculating the odds of both of those coincidences, which one would hit the buzzer first.

Thursday personal best! TGI PlDAY and not 3.2 day! I loved ALBERTEISTEIN and STEPHENHAWKINGS, of course! 

The clue for ALONE will likely leave me with a BADDREAM üò±.

The only nit I have is OHO. This must have been used just to make the grid work because who says that for ‚Äúgotcha!‚Äù? No one, that‚Äôs who.

Other than that, the clues were clever and fun. I struggled with RIATA because I didn‚Äôt know about the vaqueros (or vaqueiros here in Portugal). What a fun rabbit hole to have gone down! Since I only recently began using sunscreen (melanin no longer protects against UV rays, if it ever did), I didn‚Äôt automatically know RUBON. I put crazy words like lob and dab ü§™. The answer was obvious after my journey into cattle roping in the Americas.

Fun!! Great job!

Department of PI DAY deaths:

On March 14, 1883, Karl Marx made his greatest contribution. He died.

(Note: only six people showed up at his funeral.)

Very cute theme for 3/14.  I actually counted out the rows and columns like the clue asked (riase your hand if you did as well). Not being an American, it took me forever to find my mistake as I had GReY rather than GRAY (I wouldn't think of ADA as a Canadian). I really felt like I was on the  constructor's wavelength with this one, because it solved more like a Tuesday, probably close to a personal best. I started the puzzle hoping for a rebus, but now I'm hungry for pie.
Quick Thursday. Thanks, needed that.
Really enjoyed this puzzle.  Thank you for an enjoyable solve.

Wonderful theme and realisation of this crossword, thank you! Would have loved it even more if Ada Lovelace could have made an appearance too, being such a clever lady with her beloved numbers, but it must be frustratingly hard to make everything fit around the blacks and seeds as it is. 

She has a great name for crossword construction though‚Ä¶ ahem Emus take not pls.
Didn‚Äôt take no EINSTEIN to figure out this theme. Sorry, had to say it.

Is it irrational that a number that is defined as the ratio of the circumference to the diameter is considered irrational?

No need to explain. I know what an irrational number is.  Just found it funny that a ratio was irrational.
I can't believe I am saying this but I think I am actually jonesing for a rebus....

Loved the grid and was really impressed by the clever theme and always like lots of theme related entries.

Not theme related, but enjoyed learning who said ‚ÄúCourage is knowing what not to fear‚Äù  22D.   Hopefully I‚Äôll remember that. 

I won‚Äôt be complaining that it was too easy

Usually I struggle with Thursdays, fine them more of a chore than a game, but this puzzle was an absolute pleasure! From the grid design to the clever clues, I enjoyed enough to share with my husband and friend group chat this morning. After reading the constructor was an engineering student, I wasn't surprised that I was vibing with the clues - any engineer will have BADDREAMS about EULER. Thanks for an enjoyable start to my day! Will have some pie later to celebrate a Thursday record.

Working around the grid constraint, Jeffrey managed to come up with some pretty good fill.

Fun and fast.  Hopefully we get a nice tough one tomorrow. 

40 A was a missed opportunity to clue it as Mathemetician Lovelace.  It would have been especially nice for women's history month.

Three point one four one five nine. Come on boys, hold that line. I used to be a math guy, so I caught on pretty early with this one - noting the clue for 7d and then verifying that there were 14 rows. Not quite a record time for me, but close. Couldn't help but think about another old math joke (pies are round), and went and did a search for PIRSQUARED. That led me to a fun puzzle - a Thursday from March 27, 2014 by Jean O'Conor. In that one the symbol for PI was a rebus in two squares, with the down answers being (PI)RSQUARED and (2)(PI)R. And the answers that crossed the symbol were: LIFEOF(PI) and MAGNUM(PI) Here's the link to that one: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/27/2014&g=21&d=D ..
Beautiful puzzle (btw œÄ is my sleep number).

I liked the spanner juxtaposed in this universal-language themed puzzle - guessing that had to be intentional?
Aside from that, this puzzle was like pudding pie - an easy treat!

Have only been doing this for a month or so and this is the first puzzle that I‚Äôve felt was really quite nice and pleasurable to complete. Not that I haven‚Äôt enjoyed others‚Äîthis one was just a step above maybe. Congrats!
Happy œÄ day! Loved this puzzle. Baking a chicken pot pie tonight for celebration.

Jeffrey Martinovic, you made my day. Clueing was ‚Äúas easy as pi‚Äù for me. 

As my grandma said after a meal, ‚Äúpi is served!‚Äù 

Yum!

Loved it.

We are empty-nesters, but when the house was full, most Friday nights were
Movie-and-Pie-Night.

We took turns choosing a movie
and a pie that (somehow) related to the movie.

Moneyball and apple pie.
Casablanca and Key Lime.

Halfway through the movie, we‚Äôd pause, fill plates and bowls with pie, and finish the movie.

But once a year it was
*Double-Movie-and-Pie-Night‚Äù
3/14!!

Pizza pies (usually, though once shepherd‚Äôs and once chicken pot pies) at the start of the movie, the dessert pie halfway through.

Then, carb comas with everyone snuggled on the couches.

I believe all agree it‚Äôs our favorite family tradition.
We still keep it up, though it‚Äôs rare to have the brood home‚Ä¶

Happy Pi Day, all!
Double-pie if you dare!

Golly, what a ton of fun! Not only do we get Christopher Robin involved in Winnie-the-Pooh's hilariously clever scheme to con the bees out of their honey, but we also get three more of the wee pup BB's heroes, especially Euler. E! 

BB sends a full-bodied, fruity ARF! in recognition and thanks. 

Happy Pi Day to all.
I spent way too long trying to avoid what turned out to be the expected answer for 16 across.  Still don‚Äôt get why the word order is reversed.

We usually celebrate pi day by pampering our cat Pye (short for Pyewacket). Her name comes from an old Jimmy Stewart movie called ‚ÄúBell, Book, and Candle,‚Äù in which a cat puts a spell on people. The cat in the movie is Siamese; ours is a black American Shorthair. But Pye charmed us at the shelter 8 years ago, so we think she‚Äôs pretty aptly named. Happy pi (Pye) Day!

I thought this was a fun and satisfying Pi Day puzzle! 

I confess that I've never heard the word RIATA before, and coupled with the ATL cross I was trying to make some sort of rebus to get to the word "lariat". Turns out I was overthinking, as I am wont to do.

@debamien As a math teacher, I had several students challenge themselves to memorizing over 100 digits of pi. Thanks to a rousing cheer from our alma mater I can always remember 5.
Sine, Cosine, Cosine, Sine
3.14159
Go Science!

As a budding constructor I am in awe of the beautiful theme and grid today . To those who thought it was too easy for a Thursday - just enjoy the beauty of the puzzle . Stats like speed of solving are truly meaningless if you can't enjoy the process . Now to have some pie ! 
As an addendum , this year I enjoyed my first slice of huckleberry pie right outside of Glacier National Park - best slice of the year !

This was a fantastic Thursday puzzle!!  For me the ‚Äúaha‚Äù didn‚Äôt come to me until the very last letter (which was the 33 down) and then all the subtle clues popped out at once!!  Including the black squares!  Bravo!!

Way, way too easy for a Thursday. Solved it in 3:14.

The USA is essentially the *only* country that uses the MM/DD/YYYY format for dates. Pi Day should be July 22! (That's 22/7 for the Americans reading.) 

Given the role of mathematics as a "universal language", having THETOWEROFBABEL spanning the grid was a bit jarring to this mathematician.

‚ö´

You can‚Äôt please everyone and today ‚Äòeveryone‚Äô is me.
Nothing wrong with the grid; smart clues, clever concept. But to someone as numerically dyslexic as I am, even the mention of anything maths based brings me out in a cold sweat. I had no idea what the shape in the grid was (Tori gate?), I have no idea today is Pi day (not sure it‚Äôs a thing here?) and I have no clue what 3/14 means. Doesn‚Äôt help that we write our dates the other way round to the US system. See? Onto a complete loser for this poor, numerically challenged soul.

I salute the constructor and everyone who got a kick out of the theme. I did complete, thanks to great answers like PURPLE PROSE, plus I did work out the scientists, but the joy was lost on me. Ah well, onwards and upwards.

PS. Please, please don‚Äôt anyone try to explain Pi to me. I‚Äôm quite serious; any maths based discussions trigger awful memories of the complete misery that was years of evil maths teachers, including one that used to throw heavy chalk board cleaners at me when I couldn‚Äôt answer a question. Sadly his aim was better than my reactions; he actually concussed me once. Wouldn‚Äôt get away with it today.
My only issue with this puzzle is that in the UK and Germany (for the two big answers), the date is written as 14.3 or 14/3.  Not quite Pi.
Sure sure, the theme was cute, and me, a math hater, saw it immediately. But how about the bookending of the METs and ATL Braves?
happy truncated (3.1415) not rounded (3.14159-->3.1416) Pi day, American Pi, anyway. great puzzle, great song: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fnDDV-HgYkA

A clever and very enjoyable puzzle. But the sloppy phrase "center around" (35 Down) annoys me wherever it appears. And I'm not alone. " 'Do not write center around,' The New York Times Manual of Style and Usage says, 'because the verb means gather at a point. Logic calls for center on, center in or revolve around.' " https://www.cjr.org/language_corner/center_on_revolve.php

Most readers here may be aware of this, but for the few who may not, an interesting factoid. MIT traditionally sends out its undergrad admission letters on Pi Day. Often, the letters are released at 6:28 PM, known as ‚ÄúTau Time‚Äù (Pi x 2). An exception was made on March 14, 2015 (‚ÄúSuper Pi Day‚Äù) as that date reflected the value to five decimal places (3.1415). The letters were sent out at 9:26 AM, the next three digits. 
I‚Äôll see myself out‚Ä¶.
Easy as pi-e! Too bad the rest of the world uses dd/mm and can't have any yummies today. And the SI yyyy/mm/dd is a real party pooper! Pass the ice cream, please.
Excellent. Very satisfying to solve. Normally elaborate grids require quite a number of crosswordese to get the job done. This grid had very few of them. Great job.
Glad to see the more important constant, e, get a shout out in this puzzle.
Great story, Deb! üòÜ

I saw the big grid TT sign and immediately thought of that wonderful Sunday Pi rebus puzzle from a number of years ago. (I'm now going crazy because, once again, I've forgotten the name of the constructor so I can't track it down. Welcome to the fuzzy world of what's laughingly known as my memory.)  Anyway, I was afraid that this puzzle would steal that brilliant theme idea and do something very similar.  But it didn't.

This was a lot of very noticeable grid design for what seems to me a very tiny payoff.  PI DAY isn't much in the way of themers and as for the grid-spanners, ALBERT EINSTEIN and STEPHEN HAWKING, while they may be scientists, I don't think that either one had much, if anything, to do with PI.  They certainly didn't discover it and I'm not sure they needed to use it for anything either. 

Maybe PLATO did?  More likely EULER?  But they're not grid-spanning answers, so they pale in comparison, puzzle-wise.

Yes, today is PI DAY.  And, for all you constructors out there who haven't been able to get a puzzle into the NYT, here's one possible avenue.  Pick a holiday, any holiday, and build a puzzle around it.  If it's any good at all, it will probably up your chances considerably.

PS -- Can someone help me out with identifying that epic Sunday PI rebus?  It's driving me crazy.
Absolutely stunning puzzle!
I can‚Äôt believe it. I finished the Thursday puzzle without peeking! Hope I don‚Äôt get a big head.

The Times mentioned Dr. Goodwin's efforts, in "Topics of the Times", March 14, 1897.  The article is tongue-in-cheek polite about it.  "The tri-section of angles and the duplication of cubes can be easily done by those who accept his logic and his formulae, and doubtless the Indiana statesmen, if he asks them to do it, will make his solutions of those ancient problems also a part of the State laws."
GREAT puzzle today- what fun!!!! Happy pi day everyone!

userDisplayName: SOTU: Fiery, Feisty, and on Adderall
commentBody:
Jeffrey‚Äôs tribute to PI DAY is nice.

The cherry on top: Congrats to Elon for a successful PI DAY orbital launch of Starship!
Happy Pi Day! Nicely themed. A few days ago, it was Super "Mar10" day! Twas my granddaughter who pointed that out to me.

Is anyone else troubled by cluing "NTH" as "Last in a series"?   An online dictionary gives the definition:  "denoting an unspecified member of a series of numbers or enumerated items."   This is how I've always used it.

I offer you a slice of a virtual Lemon Meringue ( my favorite.)

Fun puzzle.
Thank you Jeffrey!
Perhaps a smidge easy for a Thursday but brilliant otherwise!
Did anyone else search up ‚Äúriata Spanish‚Äù only to be met with some very‚Ä¶ different definitions?
I always thought pi day should be April 31, in keeping with it's scientific roots.  No matter that the day doesn't happen.  All the more appropriate in fact
Loved today‚Äôs puzzle! Made my day. Thank you.
I'm making two large pizzas for my book club tonight. Had no idea how appropriate that would be until this puzzle.

I‚Äôm not usually a fan of Thursdays, but this had a nice flow. 
I ended up with my best Thursday time.

I've been busy with tax season and while I squeeze in time for the puzzle and Wordplay, I haven't had time to read the comments here from all you "wordy" people (which I miss!)

I'm posting today because not only did I enjoy the puzzle, I have reached a streak of (drum roll) 314!  On Pi Day!

See you in mid-April!
Pi is not just about circles.  It is all over waves,  whether electromagnetic, mechanical, gravity or the ones you surf on the beach, Pi (and E) is literally everywhere in the natural world.

This kind of Pi is not my thing preferring apple, cherry, blueberry 
or peach. However I applaud Jeffrey Martinsville for his success in fitting all his theme pieces of Pi so smoothly into his mathy grid. 

Not a lot to eat but such juicy facts about ALBERT EINSTEIN and STEPHEN HAWKING's first and last days on this planet. What are the odds of their lives and deaths both occurring on Pi day?!

FYI, the Atlantic has published a review of Anna Shechtman's new book, "The Riddles of the Sphinx: Inheriting the Feminist History of the Crossword Puzzle." I particularly like this observation from the reviewer, Sophia Stewart: "The lexicon of crosswords, particularly highly visible ones like the Times‚Äô, is a public-facing compendium of that shared vocabulary. As both a pastime and a public good, the ideal crossword puzzle is not a test of highbrow sensibilities but, to use Hirsch‚Äôs term, an opportunity to improve one‚Äôs cultural literacy. It should encourage and reward familiarity with a wide range of cultures, preoccupations, and ephemera. In this way, crosswords might also serve a pedagogical function: to not just affirm what one already knows but beget new knowledge." Gift link here: https://www.theatlantic.com/books/archive/2024/03/riddles-of-the-sphinx-crossword-anna-shechtman-book-review/677720/?gift=SLYL4QvJgPu-vHa9bpkaBTXlIvAGV8sQDxd3kVu1oqk&utm_source=copy-link&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=share
Fun but perhaps a little too easy for a Thursday... But given the theme, well done! Happy Pi Day!
Exceptional, perfectly timed and whimsical Thursday puzzle. Thank you, Mr. Martinovic!
Happy Pi Day, everyone!

I recently did a puzzle from the archives that clued APU as, ‚Äú‚ÄòThe Simpsons‚Äô character who claims he can recite pi to 40,000 places.‚Äù (9/29/2017 by Damon Gulczynski.) Apu is a naturalized U.S. citizen who holds a Ph.D. in computer science. He graduated first in his class of seven million from ‚ÄúCaltech‚Äù (Calcutta Technical Institute) before going on to get his doctorate at Springfield Heights Institute of Technology. In the May 6, 1993 episode‚ÄùMarge in Chains‚Äù, Marge is arrested for shoplifting some liquor from the Kwik-E-Mart. During the trial, Marge‚Äôs lawyer questions the reliability of the store‚Äôs proprietor (Apu). On the stand, he says he has perfect memory and that the 40,000th digit of pi is ‚Äú1‚Äù. Check out this link for the back story of ‚ÄúPi in the Simpsons‚Äù: https://tinyurl.com/4r67bj53

Classical interpretations of THETOWEROFBABEL portray it as an impious creation of humans. 

Its placement on this grid, above the Greek letter, hence is apropos. And spewing from it is PURPLEPROSE that only makes communication even harder to understand.

I hope that the NYT also does a PI DAY themed puzzle on July 22nd. 

22/7 (how much of the rest of world expresses dates) is  closer to the true value of Pi than 3/14.

E to the x, du/dx;
E to the x/dx.
Cosine, secant, tangent, sine.
3.14159
Square root, integral, u/dv
Slip stick, slide rule, MIT. 

A little ditty I picked up somewhere. That's how I remember pi and I have added two more digits: 26.
Finished it as quickly as a normal Monday. Cute and all, but, still, booooooh!
I love this puzzle! Such a pleasure to solve!

A PB on Pi Day! Those two scientists came to me immediately and then it was a quick solve. I was just a little surprised the biblical clue was from Gen. 11:1, and not 3:14. But I‚Äôm just Babeling now
Happy PI day!  Thank you for an enjoyable puzzle.  I was stopped by NHL team but it all came together!

As an engineering nerd, I LOVED this puzzle. TIL Hawking died and Einstein was born on this day. And to include them to plank PIDAY on the sides?? Not to mention all the other math references. Simply amazing!! Thank you and congrats to Jeffrey!!

Easier than the usual Thursday offering. Typically takes me up to an hour. This one 23 min. Oddly the longer it takes, the more I enjoy the experience. 

As an Anthony Trollope Barchesterian character put it "It's dogged as does it."
An easy puzzle helped me set my record for Thursdays today.

This puzzle is a gem, even for me. I had to get the scientists from the crosses (and got them quickly!).

Dr Waldo is my new hero!

Yay! Yay! Hooray! Happy Pi Day to you, Mr. Martinovic; to you, Grumpy Deb; to all my fellow Wordplayers; to you, Kate*; and, I dare say, even to the Emus! Pie for everyone! My favorite holiday, as it forms the intersection of two areas I love--the intellectual (mathematics) and the culinary! (Even though a BAD DREAM for me might involve having to get four hundred pies baked by a 9 am opening time, and being unable to get the ovens to light!) I am often asked, "What is favorite thing to bake." I hate that question. How about "The last thing on my prep list." 29A is an easy but ungrammatical clue. The answer is not ‚Äúthe last part‚Äù of a series because it indicates plural unnamed members of the set, nor is even ‚Äúpart‚Äù of a series, unless the series is that of the following: ‚Äúthere are many ways to avoid enumerating a list, e.g. ‚Äú‚ÄùEt cetera‚Äù‚Äù, ‚Äúand so on‚Äù‚Äù, ‚Äúand so forth‚Äù‚Äù, or ‚Äú‚Äù[29A]‚Äù‚Äù, [29A].‚Äù

But at least TIL what ‚Äúe.g.‚Äù stands for! Gratia!
that's just too good bravo!!!

My apologies if someone has already linked to this Editor‚Äôs Note, but I couldn‚Äôt find it in today‚Äôs comments: https://tinyurl.com/mrkbfctw To Will Shortz, best wishes for a speedy and complete recovery. We hope you‚Äôll be back to work soon. To Joel Fagliano, good luck in your new role. I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôll do great. What a fun puzzle! Just finished it, as I had a hike this morning and just got back. I finished it quickly and no doubt there will be some ‚Äútoo easy‚Äù complaints. It was perfect for me today with a full docket, and I was grateful to see that mathematical expertise wasn‚Äôt required. Even English majors are familiar with Pi Day, and with the two well known scientists. And I laughed out loud when I read Deb‚Äôs account of the Indiana Pi Bill. What a treat! ü§£ Thanks, Jeffrey Martinovic, and Deb Amlen too, for making my Pi Day so much fun.

Math was never my strong area of expertise, but my 9th grade algebra teacher turned it into magic.

 It makes me think of my beloved Mr. Murray Saiken who taught algebra at Meyer Levin Jr. H.S. in 1960's Brooklyn.  He had a wry sense of humor and would tell us that, "You have to scrutinize the hypotenuse ."  When the bell rang, he would tell us to, "Pass out quietly."  What delicious memories of a special man on this special day!

Can we go back to Thursday puzzles being wacky and interesting and outside-the-box? Can we go back to the wobbly feeling where rules get thrown out the window and who knows what's going to happen next? Can we stop shying away from difficulty?

Thursday used to be my favorite day of the week, but it's lost its teeth, and this feeling of disappointment has come to be a weekly ritual. To be clear, it's not Pi Day's fault. Weak Thursdays have been piling up for a while.

Let's bring back Thursday weirdness, please!
Cherry (Pi Day) picking Einstein's birth and Hawking's death was great. Nice puzzle.

Fun puzzle! Congrats to Joel for so capably stepping up, and best wishes to Will for a complete and speedy recovery.

I just got home from work and finished the puzzle I had started at breakfast -- not much time then.  But we always celebrate Pi Day because one of my coworkers has a birthday today, too.  Along with Albert E.

I made lemon meringue and apple pies -- both with fruit from my garden trees.  I much prefer pies to cake anyway, so Pi Day is an extra bonus, in its own irrational way.

@Mrs. Beeton Years ago I worked for a firm that exchanged services with companies all over the world. Out of nowhere, we were out of balance with one of our major trading partners. I was unable to sort it out using the technology of the day, fax machines, and my limited vocabulary in our partner‚Äôs language. 

So, I found myself on a B747 heading to Europe in December in the hope that I could sort this out in time to close the books for the year. 

It turned out that our accounting system was sending out all of our invoices MM/DD/YYYY.  The date format had been changed to prepare for Y2K (who else remembers that?). They were being entered as written by the clerk on the other end. Their accounting system accepted and then ignored invoices for month 13 and higher.

I was home in time for Christmas and our invoices for the new year were in DD MMM YYYY format.

@Aitch I was at first but realized if you think about how a list is sometimes written (e.g., "The fifth and sixth options were the best"), then it becomes a play on words rather than a literal definition.

@sunny617 Ahhh.  So. NiNTH,  teNTH,  eleveNTH.  

but not eighth or twelfth.    I‚Äôm still a little unhappy with the clue, but I greatly appreciate your explanation.

@Aitch This is a case, I think, in which technical usage and ordinary conversational usage have diverged considerably. In math, n is just an unknown number, and is as likely to be in any position in a series. However, popular use has devolved into meaning "extreme" or "utmost", such as in the expression "to the NTH degree", with the implication that it is the highest or ultimate degree. https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/nth Cambridge has this definition: used to describe the most recent in a long series of things, when you do not know how many there are: I glanced at my watch for the nth time that morning. https://dictionary.cambridge.org/us/dictionary/english/nth And Collins says: 1. ADJECTIVE [ADJ n] If you refer to the most recent item in a series of things as the nth item, you are emphasizing the number of times something has happened. [emphasis] The story was raised with me for the nth time two days before the article appeared. https://www.collinsdictionary.com/us/dictionary/english/nth None of these definitions have a slang, informal, substandard or other limiting marker. I'd agree if you said that this is only loosely hinted at with "Last in a series", but that's what they're going for. It's been clued that way nine times in the Shortz Era (cf. "Utmost" 21 times, and "To the __ degree" 26 times). If you Google "1st, 2nd, nth", you'll get a bunch of hits where NTH is last in a series of ordinal numbers, literally matching the clue.

42A: Definitely nitpicking here, as Wii is technically correct (as there is a "Mario Kart Wii"), but Mario Kart is a franchise name and not the name of a specific game. There are many consoles with Mario Kart as a game; every major Nintendo console since the Super Nintendo Entertainment System has a Mario Kart, with none of them just called "Mario Kart." There's also a game on iOS and an arcade game.
New Thursday solve record for me! Love this puzzle and happy pi day everyone.

Ahem. 

Having lived and worked in schooner-rich waters for so many years, I cannot allow 1A to go without nitpick. 

There is no rule that a schooner is defined as having two MASTS. There are now, and have been, many, many schooners with more -- the most MASTS I am aware of had seven (7) MASTS. It plied the waters here in Maine a long time ago. 

There is at least one schooner operating in Maine right now with four (4) MASTS, and one with three (3) MASTS. There have been other three-MASTed schooners in the recent past, and I have been on them. 

Those of you who have driven along US 1 in years past will probably remember the hulks of the famous Hesper and Luther Little, which were stranded in the mud alongside the highway in Wiscasset. Both were four-MASTed schooners, although the Luther Little had no MASTS for a very long time, and one MAST was missing from the Hesper for many years before it finally rotted into the sea. But it did proudly sport three (3) of its original four (4) MASTS for a very long time.

Is the clue OK? I suppose so. But the clue would have been better had it referenced a hull plan that always has two MASTS, such as a yawl or a ketch. 

And that's my HARRUMPH! for the day.

I really enjoyed this one. Yes, it could have been harder but I really like lack of silly gimmicks.  I'll take more science and math words anytime.

Side note: Einstein was a great scientist but he was not known as a great mathematician.

Today it's my turn to be a snooty little pedant.

"The value of pi has been known for almost 4,000 years, ..."

Not true.  We don't know the value of pi.  We know how to define it --circumference of a perfect circle divided by the diameter.  We may know it approximately, to several tens of trillions of places or so, but a several tens of trillions of places is literally nothing compared to the actual "length" of pi, which is infinite and non-repeating.

No matter how many digits we bang out, we'll still not quite know it.  Ever.

Still, I enjoyed the puzzle and the WordPlay.  Gave me a chance to be an arrogant little jerk.

Looking for a bit of a challenge, I just did the Sunday puzzle from May 22nd, 2022. For once even I was wowed by a grid's construction - the themed entries must have been extremely hard to incorporate into the grid, and the gimmick actually made the puzzle fun and interesting, which has not always been my experience. The clueing was great, too. One of my favorite puzzles, that one - and I've done close to 600 of them, since June 2023: all the current ones and some from the 2023 and 2022 archives.
